when_to_use.point: When structuring any content with the appropriate semantic or generic element
When passing data from HTML to JavaScript without extra network calls
When controlling form behaviour with boolean attributes like required and disabled

when_to_avoid.point: Avoid data attributes for sensitive data since they are visible in the DOM
Avoid div and span when a semantic element like article or nav fits better
Avoid tabindex values greater than 0 as they break natural keyboard navigation

what_it_solves.1: Without attributes, elements have no way to carry identity, state, or configuration data.

what_it_solves.2: Without data attributes, developers resort to hidden inputs or global JS variables for DOM data.

what_it_solves.3: Without boolean attributes, toggling form field states requires adding and removing value strings.

conceptual_understanding.model: An HTML element is like a labeled box. The tag name is the type of box: a p box, a button box, an img box. Attributes are sticky notes on the outside of the box that give extra instructions: this box has id=hero, class=featured, and data-priority=high. The content is what is inside the box.

Boolean attributes work like light switches. The switch being on the wall means the light is on. Taking the switch off the wall entirely means the light is off. Writing disabled=false is like taping a note that says off to a switch that is still physically on the wall. The switch ignores the note and the light stays on.

Data attributes are like luggage tags at an airport. The suitcase is the HTML element. The tag attached to it carries machine-readable information: owner, destination, flight number. The airport systems read the tag to route the bag. JavaScript reads the data attribute to route the data, without the user ever seeing the tag.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using tabindex values above 0: Setting tabindex=1 or higher pulls that element to the very front of the tab order regardless of where it appears in the document. This breaks the natural top-to-bottom keyboard navigation flow and creates a confusing experience for keyboard-only users. Only ever use tabindex=0 or tabindex=-1.

Trying to disable boolean attributes by setting them to false: Writing disabled=false or checked=false does not remove the attribute or toggle it off. The browser sees the attribute is present and treats it as true regardless of its value. To deactivate a boolean attribute, remove it entirely using removeAttribute in JavaScript or simply omit it in HTML.

Storing sensitive data in data attributes: Data attributes are fully visible to any user who opens browser DevTools. Never store passwords, tokens, private user information, or any security-sensitive values in data- attributes. Use server-side sessions or secure HTTP-only cookies for sensitive data.

bonus_tips.tip: Use the CSS attribute selector with data attributes to apply styles based on state without adding extra classes. For example: [data-theme='dark'] applies dark styles, [data-status='error'] applies error styles. This keeps your styling tied to meaningful data rather than arbitrary class names, making the intent clear.

In JavaScript, document.querySelectorAll('[data-lazy]') selects all elements that have a data-lazy attribute regardless of its value. This pattern lets you declaratively mark elements in HTML and then initialize them with a single JS selector rather than assigning individual IDs or classes.

conceptual_understanding.model: Global attributes are like passport fields that every traveller carries regardless of nationality: name, date of birth, nationality. These fields exist on every passport because every person needs them. HTML global attributes are the same: id, class, lang, and hidden are the universal fields every element carries regardless of its tag type.

A boolean attribute is a door latch, not a door lock. The latch being installed means the door is latched. Removing the latch means it is not latched. You cannot write 'unlatched' on the latch to make it inactive. The only way to unlatch is to remove it. disabled='false' is writing 'unlatched' on a latch that is still physically installed.

bonus_tips.tip: Use the hidden attribute instead of CSS display:none when you want an element invisible and also excluded from the accessibility tree. Elements with display:none are invisible but still exist in the DOM. Elements with hidden are excluded from both layout and the accessibility tree, meaning screen readers will not announce them at all.

content.title: Security Warning
content.text: Data attributes are fully visible in browser DevTools to any user. Never store passwords, API tokens, session IDs, or any sensitive user data in data- attributes. Use server-side sessions or secure HTTP-only cookies for private data.

conceptual_understanding.model: Data attributes are like luggage tags at an airport check-in. The suitcase is the HTML element. The tag attached to it carries machine-readable information: owner ID, destination, flight number. The baggage system reads the tag to route the bag without opening it. JavaScript reads the data attribute to route logic, without the user ever seeing the tag.

The dataset API is a bilingual translator sitting between HTML and JavaScript. HTML speaks kebab-case: data-product-id. JavaScript speaks camelCase: productId. The dataset object is the translator that converts between them automatically. You write in whichever language fits the context and dataset handles the conversion.

bonus_tips.tip: Use the CSS attr() function inside a content property to display a data attribute value as visible text without any JavaScript. For example: [data-count]::after { content: ' (' attr(data-count) ')'; } renders the count inline after the element. This is useful for badges, labels, and tooltips driven purely by data attributes.

subtopics.title: HTML Div and Span Elements
subtopics.description: Div and span are generic containers used only when no semantic HTML element fits the content needed.

text.value: generic container. It starts on a new line and takes the full available width. The

generic container. It flows within text without breaking the line. Neither element has semantic meaning. They exist purely for styling hooks and JavaScript targets when no suitable semantic element exists. Always prefer a semantic element like
over div whenever the content has meaning.

content.title: When to Use div and span
content.text: Use div when you need a block container purely for layout or styling and no semantic element fits. Use span when you need to target a portion of inline text with CSS or JavaScript and no semantic inline element like strong, em, or code fits.

conceptual_understanding.model: Div and span are the blank sticky notes of HTML. When you have a specific idea, you write it on a labelled card: article, nav, strong, em. When you just need something to stick there and the label does not matter, you use a blank sticky note. The blank notes are useful but they should not replace the labelled ones when a label exists.

The difference between div and span is the same as the difference between a paragraph break and a word in a sentence. Div is a paragraph break: it starts a new block, takes the full width, and pushes content before and after it onto separate lines. Span is a word: it flows inline within surrounding text without disrupting the line.

bonus_tips.tip: When you find yourself writing class names like div.header, div.footer, div.nav, or div.article, that is a signal to replace each div with its semantic HTML equivalent: header, footer, nav, and article. Semantic elements are free built-in labels that give your structure meaning without any extra CSS or JavaScript.
